comments.author: japdelarosa
comments.body:
Within the ## 5. More to be added, it could be considered the use case specific for the Coherent pluggable optics:

## 5. Coherent pluggable optics (focusing on the coherent pluggable)
o	### a. Provisioning of the Coherent pluggable optics and related parameters (e.g. Client Interface Speed, Line Interface Speed, Frequency, FEC, Modulation, Transmitted Power, SFP Identifier or Reference Number, etc.). Different phases of the implementation shall require different actions for setting the parameters either automatically or by user-defined specifications manually. It included the Network Controllers and the MDSC interactions (e.g. P-PNC to Coherent Pluggable, P-PNC / MDSC, etc.).
o	### b. Discovery / Visibility of the Coherent pluggable optics and related parameters. The above discovery includes inventory discovery by each controller and exposure to the MDSC of the required information for a complete view of the network.
o	### c. Event/fault management of the Coherent pluggable optics and related parameters.
o	### d. Performance management of the Coherent pluggable optics and related parameters.
o	### e. Reconfiguration management of the Coherent pluggable optics following network changes, faults or  and related parameters
o	### f. Correlation of coherent pluggable optics with related nodes and services items (e.g., Port/Interface, Board, Node, Services, etc.).

comments.body: Here You probably meant draft-poidt-ccamp-actn-poi-pluggable-02 instead of draft-ietf-teas-actn-poi-pluggable-02

I think we should clarify the Optical Restoration from Optical Protection. I agree the Optical protection is not needed as the packet layer is efficient on implementing the traffic protection while I would consider the Optical Restoration useful to recover the optical failure and keep the Router connectivity safe after a fiber cut.

We could add two sub-use cases, one were the central frequency is maintained (the path in OLS is restored , but keeping the frequency) (Question  is if it is worth the complexity vs the number of solvable situations).  A second sub-use is where the central frequency is allowed to change (covering more use cases).

Within the Automation/Fulfillment section, we can add 
1) Provisioning of optical connection from plug-to-plug
2) Provisioning of IP link with optical connection from plug-to-plug
.....

My comment from last week just adding a note here.  Related to SR-TE  and that the future direction for all providers is to move towards SR-TE, however the there are today technical gaps with SR related to bandwidth management due to SR being stateless that exists in RSVP TE that is statefull, where PCALC provides the auto bandwidth capabilities to provide prioritization of tunnels with DS-TE or setup/hold priorities and other statefull mechanisms for bandwidth management.   I think it maybe a good idea to mention CS-SR (circuit style SR) draft below and make a normative reference the concept draft below as that is exactly what CS-SR is about which is using SR for POI solution.  I believe vendors are working on making enhancements in near future to PCE making a v2 PCE that has a bandwidth management capabilities so that RSVP-TE statefull concepts and features can be possible in SR's stateless framework using SR-PM and path tracing.  
CS-SR draft 
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-schmutzer-spring-cs-sr-policy/ 

Cisco has a marketing buzz word they use "RON" routed optical networking which I think does make sense intuitively with RON that now a router with low profile pluggable optics can transform into a DWDM switch and provide POI integration at lower cost & sustainability.    I think RON terminology I think could be mentioned in the draft as being synonymous to POI.

I agree I with RSVP-TE  existing deployments and future SR-TE that the IP layer can provide sufficient protection for working & protect path, and optical layer to provide the restoration of fiber cut, restoring IP layer router connectivity.  I agree we could add sub use cases.
